FacilityName: City of Mansfield Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The following is an Executive Summary of the City of Mansfield, Texas Water Treatment Plant's (MWTP) 40 CFR 68 Risk Management Program,



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The MWTP's Accidental Release Prevention Policy requires training on chlorine safety, implementation of improvements identified in periodic process hazard analyses, operator as required for treatment plant operators by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ), specific training on written operating procedures developed for the plant chlorination system, training on written maintenance procedures, investigation of chlorine leaks or situations that could cause the release of chlorine, and the periodic audits of the MWTP's Risk Management Program (RMP).



The MWTP's Emergency Response Policy considers the fact that ton chlorine containers are contained in a chlorine storage building equipped with a chlorine scrubber. The MWTP has established four levels of events involving the potential for a chlorine leak or an actual chlorine leak.



Level  I.    

Chlorine containers are being delivered by the vendor or being installed by plant personnel. Response to small leaks occurring upon connection of container or during system maintenance. Valves can be closed and sections isolated for needed repair. A chlorine action form must be completed before beginning the operation. The Fire Department need not be notified.



Level  II.    

Maintenance or replacement is being performed for a faulty online device such as a tank valve. Chlorine is not being released. However, the device cannot be easily isolated or the chlorine evacuated. A chlorine action form must be completed before beginning the operation. The procedure will not begin until Fire Department personnel are adjacent to Plant in standby mode.



Level  III.    

Chlorine gas is being released but the situation is under control.  Liquid chlorine is not being released. The Chlorine Scrubber is operating properly. The

release is currently contained within the chlorine building, and the release rate is not excessive. Under no circumstances will entry be made into the chlorine storage area. Plant staff will not attempt to stop the leak. Level III represents an emergency that requires a 911 call to the Fire Department.

  

Level  IV.    

Chlorine gas is being released and the situation may  be out of control. The release rate is large or could likely become so. The release may include liquid chlorine.  The Chlorine Scrubber may not be operating. The release has or likely will escape the storage building and threaten the surrounding area. Under no circumstances will entry be made into the chlorine storage area. Any necessary repairs will be made by a trained HazMat team from either the City of Arlington or the City of Fort Worth.  MFD has mutual aid agreements with both the Arlington and Fort Worth.



The MWTP has had no accidental releases in the past five years.



The MWTP completed the Phase 4 expansion project in April 2011. The expansion included a hypochlorite generation system which will eliminate the use of chlorine for disinfection of treated water from this facility. Chlorine will continue to be used in the production of Chlorine Dioxide. This will reduce our on site capacity to (2) one ton containers. The MWTP will continue to review and evaluate chlorine procedures. Plant staff will be required to take the chlorine safety and maintenance class every three years minimum.
